target_title: Input problems with Japanese 109-key layout keyboard

note.body:
I understand an overview of how g-r-d inputs key codes.
In other words, I understand that g-r-d does not yet fully support input from Japanese 109-key keyboards.

When connecting via XRDP, the two problems I reported this time do not occur at all, so I thought that it was a problem specific to g-r-d.
It's not urgent, but with XRDP, the remote connection is via X11, not wayland.
I would like to switch to wayland, so I would like to use g-r-d if possible.
I will wait until the patch is completed.

Also, this is my first time reporting an issue on gitlab, so I don't know how to apply the patch.
Therefore, if possible, I would like you to teach me how to apply the patch.

target_title: Input problems with Japanese 109-key layout keyboard

note.body:
> Keyboard: Japanese 109-key layout

Oh, seeing this now. Let's try the first part here first, will prepare a patch for what I described above (with the keyboard type).

target_title: Input problems with Japanese 109-key layout keyboard

note.body:
> Log when pressing pipe key Dec 31 10:00:51 Fedora-Host gnome-shell\[9678\]: Unknown/invalid virtual device key 0x0 pressed Dec 31 10:00:51 Fedora-Host gnome-shell\[9678\]: Unknown/invalid virtual device key 0x0 pressed

Ah, I have a suspicion. The way keycode input works here is by getting a virtual scan code from the RDP client, which is then converted to a virtual keycode, and that to our keycode.

The virtual scancode depends on the keyboard type from https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/openspecs/windows_protocols/ms-rdpbcgr/00f1da4a-ee9c-421a-852f-c19f92343d73. The keyboard type is only submitted once (at the beginning of the connection).
Currently, g-r-d always assumes it to be IBM enhanced, which is also the case in almost all or most cases. But FreeRDP has handling for both IBM enhanced and the japanese type: https://github.com/FreeRDP/FreeRDP/blob/master/winpr/libwinpr/input/scancode.c#L123
I think g-r-d needs to lookup this value at the beginning of the session and use that for the keyboard type. However, since entering latin characters works, it might not the be the (only) issue. There is also the part of converting the virtual scan code to the virtual key code:  
This is done using the `GetKeycodeFromVirtualKeyCode()` function and the mapping in https://github.com/FreeRDP/FreeRDP/blob/master/winpr/libwinpr/input/keycode.c#L299. And that mapping does not seem to be complete. There is also a `/* TODO: Finish Japanese Keyboard */` comment inside FreeRDPs code here (the XKB and EVDEV tables are quite similar except for the index shift). I don't know with which values the mappings without keys should be filled with.

target_title: Input problems with Japanese 109-key layout keyboard

note.body:
The behavior I expect is as follows:

- When the half-width/full-width key is pressed once, the input method should switch only once.
(It should not act as if it was pressed multiple times even though it was pressed only once.)

- When the pipe key is pressed, "|" should be input.

As instructed, I added MUTTER_DEBUG=input-events to /etc/environment to reproduce the issue.

As a result, the following log was output by the journalctl command.

■ Log when pressing half-width/full-width key
Dec 31 10:00:53 Fedora-Host gnome-shell[9678]: INPUT_EVENTS: Queuing 'key-press' from (null), time=8302544868 us, modifiers=mod2, (hidden)

■ Log when pressing pipe key
Dec 31 10:00:51 Fedora-Host gnome-shell[9678]: Unknown/invalid virtual device key 0x0 pressed
Dec 31 10:00:51 Fedora-Host gnome-shell[9678]: Unknown/invalid virtual device key 0x0 pressed

I have also uploaded the log and video of the event when I reproduced it, so please check them out.

※The pipe key was pressed at 0:00:17 in the video.
A yellow log is displayed when the pipe key is pressed.

*The half-width/full-width key was pressed at 0:00:20 in the video.

[journalctl--since20241231100040--until20241231100100.txt](/uploads/1e2e28f6bb334b53879a8a3b79aafad4/journalctl--since20241231100040--until20241231100100.txt)

![2024-12-31_100212](/uploads/bdca3c00caa834385fb91855740f978c/2024-12-31_100212.mp4)

target_title: Input problems with Japanese 109-key layout keyboard

note.body:
Entering latin letters when the Japanese input method works as expected?

Can you try this:

Add `MUTTER_DEBUG=input-events` in `/etc/environment` and login again / restart the headless session.

First type something like `hello` in the terminal, switch input method and reproduce the issue, ideally with a screen recording, so I can match the input events I see queued and the result on screen.

target_title: Use Vulkan to import dma-buf images

note.body:
Pushed now an approach to directly fetch the DRM render node, when initializing the EGL thread. The DRM render nodes are now compared.  
Used though a simpler approach to compare both paths by constructing the path in Vulkan, instead of using `stat()` (we have to do the same for VAAPI, as we need to open the DRM render node there for a DRM fd).

Something to note though is, that the Vulkan docs (https://registry.khronos.org/vulkan/specs/latest/html/vkspec.html#external-memory-handle-types-compatibility, https://registry.khronos.org/vulkan/specs/latest/html/vkspec.html#external-semaphore-handle-types-compatibility, https://registry.khronos.org/vulkan/specs/latest/html/vkspec.html#external-fence-handle-types-compatibility) mention, that having the same driver and device UUID is required, when choosing external types such as opaque fds (we currently don't, so it's fine).

I think comparing the DRM render nodes is good though (need the DRM render node of the EGL thread anyway for explicit sync, if no Vulkan is available), because I don't know if the device UUIDs are unique per device itself and not per device type (e.g. when having multiple GPUs installed of the same type).

target_title: Use Vulkan to import dma-buf images

note.body:
> What I could try though is your suggestion above and check `EGL_DRM_DEVICE_FILE_EXT` with the DRM device from Vulkan (`VK_EXT_physical_device_drm`).

Ah, yes indeed. You can get the major/minor from `EGL_DRM_DEVICE_FILE_EXT` using

```c
  struct stat st;

  ret = stat (path, &st);
```

then compare those with the relevant major/minor field in `VkPhysicalDeviceDrmPropertiesEXT`.

target_title: Use Vulkan to import dma-buf images

note.body: Yes, indeed. I put this in this MR, so that the VAAPI MR would be a little less larger. I can still move this a little more up in the history, so it would be part of the VAAPI MR (where this is used).

target_title: Use Vulkan to import dma-buf images

note.body:
The suggestion to compare both the driver UUID and device UUID was mentioned by an NVIDIA dev in their forum (https://forums.developer.nvidia.com/t/sharing-render-buffers-or-render-textures-among-multiple-opengl-contexts/77168/24) (Originally, I shared the same memory between GL and Vulkan before using a zero-copy approach later).

The thing with the device name would not work. Via `vulkaninfo` and `glxinfo`, I get different results in Vulkan and GL:
for Vulkan I get `Intel(R) HD Graphics 4600 (HSW GT2)` and for GL I get `Mesa Intel(R) HD Graphics 4600 (HSW GT2) (0x416)`. Haven't checked this on the Tigerlake laptop, but this here already is not consistent.

What I could try though is your suggestion above and check `EGL_DRM_DEVICE_FILE_EXT` with the DRM device from Vulkan (`VK_EXT_physical_device_drm`).

target_title: README: Add documentation how to use gnome-remote-desktop

note.body:
hm.. the headless daemon of g-r-d is rather unknown. Most people will directly associate remote login with it. And it doesn't matter how often we tell people, that the headless daemon is not the system daemon for remote login, [they won't understand it](https://gitlab.gnome.org/GNOME/gnome-user-docs/-/issues/260#note_2156641).

So, the `in an independently set up headless graphical user session` information will be discarded by them, when reading that.  
Also since people associate the headless daemon with remote login, they will then see `single user`, and then tell others in forums that remote login only allows one user in general, which is not the case.

Not sure, how to do that better. But possibly the actual remote login section should be placed above this one and maybe it should be explicitly stated (in this section (headless case)), that this is not about remote login, but a rather small use case, where users should know what they are doing. + that the remote login section is above (not sure, whether we can place links within the ReadMe here)

Mouse cursor not visible in extend mode over RDP

note.body:
First of all, thank you to the Gnome devs for creating this incredibly useful feature which I miss, literally, every day. It seems so close to working.

Just to try to add a little further information, on my Ubuntu 24.04.1 LTS (Wayland) system extended onto a similar system running FreeRDP, I can actually see fleeting glimpses of the cursor on the second screen.  If you move it quickly enough numerous cursors are left behind and then erased as you move over them again.  It's as though when the cursor moves (in the area of the second screen) the area where the cursor was is not refreshed quickly enough and the image is left behind. 
I can also confirm that if you move the cursor over an active screen element like a button, it changes colour and can be clicked. Also any movement in the second screen is frozen when the cursor is moved back to the 'home' screen.

Let's hope the new merge mentioned by darkblaze69 recently will fix the issue.

Microphone recording redirection happens even when the client does not request audio forwarding?

note.body:
> and to save a bit of bandwidth.

Btw disabling audio input redirection (microphone input) won't really save bandwidth, because the way g-r-d (MS Windows RDS does that btw too) setups the audio source is, that audio samples are only transmitted, when an audio application running on the server side actually requests audio samples from the microphone. Both g-r-d and MS Windows RDS do this by dynamically open and closing the respective DVC.  
g-r-d notices this, when PipeWire pauses or resumes the audio stream.

target_title: Microphone recording redirection happens even when the client does not request audio forwarding?

note.body:
Whether microphone redirection should happen or not is defined in `2.2.1.11.1.1 Info Packet (TS_INFO_PACKET)` with the `INFO_AUDIOCAPTURE` flag.

If the client wants microphone redirection, it sets that flag. But the that does not mean, that microphone redirection will actually take place. When the server then attempts to open the respective audio input DVC, the client must also successfully respond to the DVC creation request, otherwise microphone redirection cannot take place.

This means regardless of what happens, if there is a security issue, it is on the client side (because it is the side, that actually sends the audio samples and such).
I just checked the situation with xfreerdp3 and it works as expected here: By default xfreerdp3 does not advertise microphone redirection, and g-r-d does not even try to setup it.
When specifying `/microphone` on the cmdline too, microphone redirection is wanted, and g-r-d indeed setups the DVC and audio source.

Btw just checked and Remmina it works here. You disabled audio **output** redirection in your screenshot. But audio output redirection is not microphone input, it is audio input redirection.

So, no issue in g-r-d here, closing.

target_title: Microphone recording redirection happens even when the client does not request audio forwarding?
Microphone recording redirection happens even when the client does not request audio forwarding?
Cannot connect to remote

note.body:
for those having issues, this is how I fixed it:

```
STEP1:
disable gui remote login

STEP2:
# Server
RDP_USER="${USER}"
RDP_PASS="12345678"
sudo dnf -y install gnome-remote-desktop freerdp
sudo -u gnome-remote-desktop winpr-makecert \
    -silent -rdp -path ~gnome-remote-desktop rdp-tls
sudo grdctl --system rdp enable
sudo grdctl --system rdp set-credentials "${RDP_USER}" "${RDP_PASS}"
sudo grdctl --system rdp set-tls-key ~gnome-remote-desktop/rdp-tls.key
sudo grdctl --system rdp set-tls-cert ~gnome-remote-desktop/rdp-tls.crt
sudo systemctl --now enable gnome-remote-desktop.service
sudo firewall-cmd --permanent --add-service=rdp
sudo firewall-cmd --reload

STEP3:
xfreerdp3 /v:192.168.2.2 /u:USER /p:12345678 /sec:nla
```

Multi-monitor support

note.body:
With regard to this:

> In addition to that the remote desktop interface or the PW handling needs to be adjusted so that g-r-d can position virtual monitors, submit monitor scales for them, and set a virtual monitor as the primary one.

Currently this feature is quite usable for headless sessions and the only annoyance is this loss of monitor layout configuration persisting.

It appears that [progress is being made to get sessions to save/restore window geometry in Gnome 48](https://www.phoronix.com/news/Mutter-XDG-Session-Management) via recent PR [mutter!3825](https://gitlab.gnome.org/GNOME/mutter/-/merge_requests/3825) so saving the monitor layout would allow for remote sessions to properly restore windows starting with 48

target_title: Google Chrome color issue only when connected via gnome-remote-desktop (grd) in Gnome 47

note.body: Accessing it via VNC and cockpit is likely using qemu and it's vnc access. That means gnome-shell is using KMS, while when using gnome-remote-desktop, no particular display related kernel feature is enabled. It'd be interesting to see the journal output of gnome-shell for when you reproduce it. It'd also be interesting to know how you run grd - is it single user headless, headless remote login, or screen share?

target_title: Google Chrome color issue only when connected via gnome-remote-desktop (grd) in Gnome 47

note.body: From grd's perspective, it has no information about what part of the screen is Chrome, and what is Firefox. All it sees are the pixels that make up the whole screen, so if all applications except Chrome behaves incorrectly, it's most likely something client side, be it Chrome itself, or the OpenGL / Vulkan driver, whatever they are using these days.

target_title: Google Chrome color issue only when connected via gnome-remote-desktop (grd) in Gnome 47
Screen geometry is lost when disconnecting

note.body: Duplicate of https://gitlab.gnome.org/GNOME/gnome-remote-desktop/-/issues/11. While the initial parts for multi-monitor handling (creating, destroying, resizing them) are implemented, there is no mutter API yet to position, to submit scales, or submit other info about the monitors to mutter.

target_title: Handle systems without permission to hardware acceleration

note.body:
> render nodes are not part of a seat, and remote desktop sessions aren't associated with a seat either. So render nodes never get tagged uaccess

Ah, I see.

> I suppose logind could give render node access to users associated with remote sessions access as long as the session is open. I guess it could be implemented with some new `uremoteaccess` tag on the device nodes, and some new rule in udev that assigns it to `/dev/dri/renderD*` something like that. It would need buy in from the systemd crew.

If that could be implemented, that would be great.

target_title: Terminal doesn't get repainted

note.body:
This is an issue in mutter. Or rather: was, because it was already fixed long time ago and landed in mutter-46.3 (and 47+). Since you haven't provided any version information, I assume you are using GNOME 46.  
According to https://launchpad.net/ubuntu/+source/mutter, Ubuntu still does not ship mutter-46.3 or later (last 46.x version is already 46.6), so this is a downstream issue.  
This is an issue with Ubuntu in general, upstream updates rarely reach users (issue is actually fixed upstream, but Ubuntu (downstream) does not ship an updated package for the respective project).

So, please create an issue in the issue tracker of your distribution. It is their responsibility to ship upstream updates. Closing.

target_title: Terminal doesn't get repainted
Handle systems without permission to hardware acceleration

note.body:
you can't really add a user to a group securely because once a user is in a group they can just `chmod g+s` a binary and come back to that group any time they want. They can never truly be revoked unless all mounts are locked down with `nosuid`. so i don't really see the point of leveraging a `render` group, it's mostly security theater. probably the best approach would be to have logind apply acls for a user when a remote session is registered, and revoke the acl when removed.

but i also think just leaving the render node open is a lot easier :-)

target_title: Handle systems without permission to hardware acceleration

note.body:
So the way it works afaik is the udev rules mark any drm card device to part of a seat. by default this is seat0 but that can be changed with a loginctl command.

Any device that's part of a seat gets tagged "uaccess" which means logind will automatically add and remove access to the device node for the users using active sessions from active seats on the system.

render nodes are not part of a seat, and remote desktop sessions aren't associated with a seat either. So render nodes never get tagged uaccess and even if they did, logind would never give access to remote users trying to use them.

To be honest I see little advantage to restricting access to render nodes for users. It seems like they're designed for headless use cases, including like test suites and such, so it doesn't seem like a great idea to lock them down... And it seems like a better approach to locking them down would be selinux policy or something like that than using fs acls.

I suppose logind could give render node access to users associated with remote sessions access as long as the session is open. I guess it could be implemented with some new `uremoteaccess` tag on the device nodes, and some new rule in udev that assigns it to `/dev/dri/renderD*` something like that. It would need buy in from the systemd crew.

target_title: Handle systems without permission to hardware acceleration

note.body: When Debian applied the systemd upstream change to add the render group, Debian [used](https://salsa.debian.org/systemd-team/systemd/-/commit/8ca0c4921b) the permission 0660 instead of 0666 like upstream recommended.

target_title: Terminal doesn't get repainted
Handle systems without permission to hardware acceleration

note.body:
> Only the user, who enabled g-r-d via g-c-c would then have GPU access.

(unless we only show the users in the remote greeter (remote gdm screen), that have access to the GPU with some additional message, that other users don't have permission to remotely login, unless they are added to the `render` group)

target_title: Handle systems without permission to hardware acceleration

note.body:
One thing, that I am thinking about, but don't have the expertise is using ACLs: For example, `/dev/dri/card0` has on most or all distributions restrictions too.  
It cannot be accessed by the user (unless manually added to the video group, which is normally not the case). However, there is also an ACL, that permits the current physical user to have access to `/dev/dri/card0`.  
I wonder, whether we could somehow add something similar to g-r-d (e.g. via some systemd magic) to trigger something similar with the render nodes (`/dev/dri/renderD128`) here?

target_title: Handle systems without permission to hardware acceleration

note.body:
> Or if it's safe enough to just add the user to the group by default if it has graphical session access abilities

I think so, yes. CPU resources are in any case more precious than GPU resources (bottleneck-wise).

> Wondering if it could be the case to improve g-c-c to do add the user to the group via polkit request when remote desktop is enabled.

One downside though would be, when there are multiple users, that want to use remote login. Only the user, who enabled g-r-d via g-c-c would then have GPU access. Other users would still only have software rendering (this is regardless how many users use the system at the same time).

target_title: Handle systems without permission to hardware acceleration

note.body:
Wondering if it could be the case to improve g-c-c to do add the user to  the group via polkit request when remote desktop is enabled.

Something to toggle at build time, so it won't affect all distros.

Or if it's safe enough to just add the user to the group by default if it has graphical session access abilities

target_title: Mouse cursor not visible in extend mode over RDP

note.body:
To whoever finds itself in this situation I found two lame(but valid) workarounds while the devs solve this question.

**1**-There is a gnome extension called "**Eye On Cursor**" that draws an illustration on screen that follows your cursor.

When your cursor enters the virtual screen it doesn't show up in the client, but the illustration will.

In a first moment I found the illustration too big an intrusive, the extension doesn't let you shrink it lower than 128x128px.
I then gave a little tweak in it's script at:
`~/.local/share/gnome-shell/extensions/eye-on-cursor@djinnalexio.github.io/settings/trackerSettings.js`

Line 103, "**#region Tracker size**" section, "**lower**" and "**step_increment**" variables, set them to "**8**"

Reload the extension and voila, you can reduce the illustration size to the point it's just a small dot under your cursor.

~~________________________________________~~

**2**-If your client OS is Windows you can use the TightVNC client, it shows the cursor properly.

BUT:
- TightVNC doesn't support TLS authentication, I wouldn't use it on untrusted networks. (the VNC protocol itself doesn't support passwords over 8 digits, which is big problem by today's security standards) 
- You can't change the screen resolution, it's 1920x1080.
- The refresh rate is frustrating bad.
- You will need to use the terminal to configure it, on Fedora 40 I used:
```
grdctl vnc set-auth-method password
grdctl vnc set-password [your_pass_8_digits_max]
gsettings set org.gnome.desktop.remote-desktop.vnc screen-share-mode 'extend'
gsettings set org.gnome.desktop.remote-desktop.vnc encryption "['none']"
gsettings set org.gnome.desktop.remote-desktop.vnc enable true
systemctl --user enable gnome-remote-desktop.service
systemctl --user start gnome-remote-desktop.service
```

note.body: Ideally regular users should indeed be allowed access to the render nodes if they can also login to a real session, otherwise headless remote sessions are going to get a pretty sub-par experience. Would be good to get some input on how these distributions intend to handle remote graphical access.

GNOME Remote Desktop with VNC cannot handle UTF-8 clipboard text

note.body: Just a note: Libvncserver reports UTF-8 clip text via `setXCutTextUTF8` callback. So I think this can be fixed by adding a `setXCutTextUTF8` handler  [here](https://gitlab.gnome.org/GNOME/gnome-remote-desktop/-/blob/0618512d17f11d68a7847ca732ebda98ea648c3b/src/grd-session-vnc.c#L652) and skipping [this](https://gitlab.gnome.org/GNOME/gnome-remote-desktop/-/blob/master/src/grd-clipboard-vnc.c?ref_type=heads#L107-109) conversion if text is already in UTF-8.
